title: Group Dissertation Supervision
text:
Overview
Under construction

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.1 Getting to know each other, topics, proposals
In the first session, the purpose is mainly to get to know each other - what topics are you interested in? We also have a look over what is required for the dissertation proposal and discuss what you can expect as part of supervision.
Every dissertation project is different, and the way I tend to supervise is to focus on us working together (both you and I, and also us as a group with your peers) to support you to develop a range of skills, culminating in your dissertation write up. I tend to be quite structured as a supervisor, and this is one reason I developed this document, as it will outline the process for you in advance, so you know what to expect. If there is something you would like added, let me know and I’ll see what I can do.

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.2 Expectations
I have certain expectations in terms of how we will work together over the academic year. I have some below, but in our first group meeting, I will ask you to think about whether there are any you would like to add, or if there is anything you want to amend related to the points below.

1.2.1 Communication
I ask that all students working with me communicate with me, letting me know if they are unable to make a certain deadline or if something gets in the way of a task they had planned for a specific point in time. In return, I will communicate with you regularly, including when you can expect feedback, and will do my best to let you know if I have to delay something beyond what I had previously communicated.


1.2.2 Attendance
I ask that all students attend group sessions unless there is something urgent that has come up. Individual drop-ins are flexible and you don’t need to attend if you feel that you don’t need to meet in a particular week. Group sessions are held for 1.5h every fortnight, with individual drop-ins held in the weeks that we are not meeting as a group.


1.2.3 Supportive space
I want the dissertation group to be an encouraging, safe, space and the dissertation process to be an enjoyable (albeit challenging at points!) experience for everyone. This means that you should never hesitate to ask any questions (all questions are valid) and I’d like us all to work together to support each other. No one is perfect and we will all make mistakes during the process (including me). I’ve been supervising for quite a few years now and I haven’t yet managed to come across anything that we have been unable to sort after some discussion, so don’t worry about talking to me if something has gone wrong :).

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.3 Dissertation meetings
Dissertation meetings will be held every week, with individual meetings and group meetings alternating on a weekly basis.
Semester 1

Group meetings: Weeks 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11
Individual drop-ins: Weeks 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12

Semester 2

Group meetings: Weeks 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11
Individual drop-ins: Weeks 2, 4, 6, 8, 10

All meetings will be held in my office. I will send outlook invitations for all supervisions, so that they are in Outlook calendars.
We will most likely have to select a different time for Semesters 1 and 2, due to changes in timetables/teaching, but can revisit this nearer to the end of Semester 1.

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.4 Deadlines
We will set deadlines for you to submit the following: proposal, ethics, introduction, methods, results/analysis. I will ask you to work with me to set these deadlines so that we agree them together.

Differences in timeline between primary and secondary data projects
Typically, intros are sent in December/early Jan, methods in Jan/Feb and Results or Analysis in Feb.
Sections can be sent together or separately, although I would recommend separate.
Everyone should choose deadlines for each section and it will be added to the deadline spreadsheet.
I have a cut off for accepting drafts. This is usually two weeks before the deadline, so you should keep this in mind when setting deadlines (give yourself some wiggle room!).
Deadline tracker- you will have to juggle the dissertation alongside other courses, so you need to work consistently on it but also take advantage of the quieter periods to work on it.


1.4.1 Ethics
For those doing primary data collection. we will prioritise the ethics application from the very start - the reason for this is that you cannot recruit data unless you have your ethics approved, meaning that delayed applications can bring a project to a halt.
For secondary data projects, your priority is the research proposal and aligning a RQ with a data source.


1.4.2 Dissertation
Dissertation section deadlines are not set in stone - I would much rather that you take an extra day or two if you need it rather than sending an unfinished draft (with the caveat that it will never be perfect). If this is the case, let me know and we can discuss options.
Although it is unusual for this to be an issue, there will be a point where I am no longer able to look over drafts before the deadline. We will aim for dates before this, but my cut-off is that I don’t accept drafts once we reach 1st March. This is because it becomes very unlikely that I will be able to turn around feedback in time for you to be able to make meaningful changes by the submission .deadline in mid-March.

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.5 Communication
I have set up a Teams with a couple of channels that you can access - I have a General one for all of my dissertation students and your individual private channels.
Please use the channel to send me any messages or sahre drafts rather than using private email. If it’s a question that the whole group would benefit from seeing the answer to, please post it on the General channel.

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.6 Feedback

1.6.1 When you can expect feedback
Generally speaking I aim to return all feedback in one week. There are certain times of the semester when my teaching load is heaviest when it might be two weeks but I will always be clear about this.


1.6.2 What type of feedback you will receive
I generally provide in-text comments, so that I can show you which part am I referring to in my feedback (where relevant). I will also give a global overview/summary. I will tend to focus on what can be improved, as this is the priority to help your writing develop. However, I will also let you know what you do well too.


1.6.3 How you can ask for specific feedback
If you have specific parts you would like feedback on (e.g. if you are unsure about something), you can leave comments in your document (either at specific points or at the start) and I will respond to them when I am reading through. Try not to put the points you’d like feedback on in the message when you send the file to me, as I put the files elsewhere and don’t tend to refer back to messages. This makes it more likely that I’ll miss them if they aren’t contained in the document when I come to read it.


1.6.4 What format should be sent for the drafts?
All documents (proposal, ethics, Intro, Methods, Results/Analysis) should be in Word. An exception to this is copies of standardised measures (this might be in pdf, which is fine).

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.7 Supervision sessions

1.7.1 Group Sessions
In each session, there will be time for questions and we will also go round the group and see how everyone’s project is going. We will also spend time discussing certain aspects of the dissertation, and I will provide resources as appropriate.
I have planned out the group sessions as follows (although these are subject to change if required):
Semester 1

Week 1: Getting to know each other, topics, proposals
Week 3: Ethics, research questions
Week 5: Summarising papers, bullet point introductions
Week 7: Discussing the bullet point intros, participant recruitment, reducing perfectionism
Week 9: Collecting data, developing evaluation (intro)
Week 11: Structure (i.e. reverse outlines), JARS guidelines

Semester 2

Week 1: Receiving and applying feedback, presenting work
Week 3: Analysis (quant and qual)
Week 5: Developing evaluation (discussion), linking in theory
Week 7: No-stakes presentations - everyone will present a 5 min summary of study findings so far (these can be very roughand initial if you haven’t completed analysis)
Week 9: Final group session - bring your questions
Week 11: Longer session: Celebration combined with practice talks for the UG conference/BPS conference



1.7.2 Individual sessions
Individual drop ins are on the weeks when we don’t meet as a group. Here, we will tend to catch up on how your project is going, and you will have the opportunity to ask questions specific to your project. These may be used more often at certain points in the year (e.g. getting ethics together) than others (e.g. once your data collection is all set up).

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.8 Peer Review
I am not allowed to look at a draft of the Discussion section, so there will be the opportunity to peer review each others’ discussion sections. We will discuss this in Semester 2, in the group sessions.
I will provide some guidelines around peer review, and you can choose whether to take part or not. I am happy to set things up for you if you want, or can take a step back and you can organise within yourselves. Everyone who wants to take part must be included.

title: 1  Semester 1 Week 1
text:
1.9 Future aspirations
I realise that some people get a bit nervous when asked the ‘what are your plans after graduation?’ question, but I will ask you about this at some point during semester 1. I will most likely do this in individual drop-ins. The reason that I do it is so that I can see if there is anything I/your peers can do throughout the dissertation process to support your future plans.
If you don’t know what you want to do, this is also fine, but it is then about seeing if we can maximise development of your employability skills, which will then be helpful in whichever direction you decide to go in :).

1.9.1 Introductions and topics

Everyone will introduce themselves and the general topic/s that you are interested in. Do you have a fixed idea or are you still deciding? Do you know what approach you want to take, methodologically? Do you have any questions?



1.9.2 Format of supervision

I will then discuss the general process of supervision

Expectations I have and what you can expect from me as a supervisor
Individual vs. group sessions (including how these differ, what the function of each is)
The importance of getting ethics done at an early stage in the process
Discuss a general timeline of the project (everyone’s will look a bit different though)

General project management:

It’s worth setting up a reference manager now if you don’t already use one (e.g. Zotero)
Project management will be very important - there’s information on using Planner in the Moodle
Use of Teams for communication and sharing drafts




1.9.3 Writing a proposal
Some things to think about:

Why are you conducting the study?
What do you want to find out? - What data will you need?
Who are you going to recruit? From where?
For secondary data, what possible sources of data can you use? How might the data need cleaned?
What would your RQ/hypotheses be?
If quant, what analysis would you do for each hypothesis?
If qual, how are you planning to analyse your data and why?

Refer to the Example Research proposal and proforma on the Level 4 dissertation Moodle - it’s all in the section labelled “Project management and time saving tools”


1.9.4 Other things to cover

Dissertation resources
Level 4 Moodle
College vs. intranet for ethics
Supervisor access to data
Using AI for your dissertation

title: 2  Semester 1 Week 3
text:
2.1 Ethics, research questions
In this session, we will talk about ethics and research questions. Depending on your project, you will either submit to secondary ethics, intranet ethics (low-risk option for Level 4 only) or College ethics (higher-risk/potential to publish for Level 4, all primary data collection for PGT)

title: 2  Semester 1 Week 3
text:
2.1.1 Expected progress and prep for the meeting

In Week 3, I would expect that you will be firming up your research questions and what your data collection/analysis will look like and have made progress in the proposal.
Read through the resources below on developing a research question.
Please bring along the draft of your proposal and research questions so far.
Decide on a deadline for when you will submit your ethics application for feedback to me. Remember that you may need multiple drafts.

Make a note of any questions or concerns you have about ethics at this stage ahead of the meeting.

title: 2  Semester 1 Week 3
text:
2.2 Internal resources

2.2.1 Developing a research question
Research Methods 1 has some tips for students on how to construct Research Questions and hypotheses for quantitative research
Research Methods 2 has some tips for students on how to construct Research Questions for qualitative research


2.2.2 Ethics
Specific to School of Psychology & Neuroscience: The Moodle (Level 4, PGT) has a folder with templates and exemplars for ethics that should be used

title: Appendix A — List of all resources

A.1 Developing a research question
Research Methods 1 has some tips for students on how to construct Research Questions and hypotheses for quantitative research

title: Appendix A — List of all resources
text:
A.2 Secondary data
If you’re using secondary data for your dissertation, this means that you’re not going to create data yourself, instead, you’re going to use data that already exists. Secondary data can offer several advantages such as saving time, resources, and providing access to a wider scope of data than might be feasible for you to collect yourself. Secondary data can come in several different forms.
Academic Research Data: Many researchers collect more data than they use in their studies. This unused data can sometimes be accessed and reanalysed to answer a different research question than was originally proposed. This data is typically rigorously collected and validated, making it a reliable source. Reanalysing this data allows you to expand upon the original research, or approach it from a new perspective.
Public Databases: Numerous governmental, institutional, or organisation-run databases exist that provide a wealth of demographic, health, societal, and other types of data. Such databases can be national or international in scope, offering a vast amount of data for potential research questions.
Social Media and Online Data: Internet sources such as social media platforms, forums, and blogs generate a vast amount of data every day. These sources can provide rich qualitative and quantitative data for various research questions. For example, a thematic analysis of posts on a specific topic on Reddit can offer insights into people’s attitudes, experiences, or behaviors. However, it’s crucial to ensure that any use of this type of data is respectful of privacy considerations and adheres to ethical guidelines.
It’s important that your research question is aligned with the data that is available to you. Start by formulating a broad research question based on the literature as you would for primary research and then start looking for sources of data that might allow you to answer that question. You’ll find that you probably have to go back-and-forth between your RQ and looking for data until you find a good alignment. This means the set-up part of your dissertation will take longer than primary data collection, but, you don’t then have the time-consuming process of data collection so it all balances out.
Finally, it’s essential to consider any ethical implications of your data sources and ensure you have the necessary permissions to access and use the data. Some secondary data sources may require you to obtain approval, provide acknowledgment, or adhere to specific usage policies. Always ensure to comply with these requirements and respect the rights of the original data collectors and participants.

Journal of Open Psychology Data 



Secondary data sources - useful blog with a list of databases you can use to source secondary data 



BPS Ethics guidelines for internet-mediated research 



Preregistration of Secondary Data Analysis Template 



Studying Reddit: A Systematic Overview of Disciplines, Approaches, Methods, and Ethics 



‘Scraping’ Reddit posts for academic research? Addressing some blurred lines of consent in growing internet-based research trend during the time of Covid-19 



Secondary Data Analysis: An Introduction for Psychologists

Examples of previous ethics applications – this folder contains ethics applications for a mixed method survey and a focus group study conducted with neurodivergent students.  
If you are submitting to College ethics you will need a copy of my CV which you can find here.

title: Appendix A — List of all resources
text:
A.4 Software
If you are collecting primary data, for surveys and questionnaires I prefer Qualtrics. We have a UofG licence and there’s more information and the login via UofG IT.  

Qualtrics is very powerful and doesn’t just do surveys, you can build experiments with randomised trials and between-subject conditions into it: Building a psychology experiment
